newsitem.title: PERU: Cyprus' Cerro Verde receives $110 mln loan. [CORRECTED 01:15 GMT]
newsitem.headline: Cyprus' Cerro Verde receives $110 mln loan. [CORRECTED 01:15 GMT]

text.p: U.S.-based Cyprus Amax Minerals Co's Sociedad Minera Cerro Verde S.A. copper mine has received a $110 million long-term loan to refinance liabilities, a leading local bank said Tuesday. (Corrects source to bank from company.)
Banco de Credito said in a statement it led and structured the loan from several local and foreign banks.
"This is the first time in more than 20 years that international commercial banking has granted direct eight-year financing to a local firm," the statement.
"This is the first time in more than 20 years that international commercial banking has granted direct eight-year financing to a local firm," the statement said.
The loan is being granted by 15 local and foreign financial institutions and its granting is "a clear indication of the resurgence of foreign banking interest in our country," it said.
The loan will be granted in two tranches, the first for $80 million to be repaid over eight years and the remainder in a second tranche to be repaid over five years, it said.
The loan will be guaranteed using future copper sales of Cyprus' local unit and certain assets.
The funds will be used to refinance short-term obligations that went to finance the company's investment program.
Cyprus bought Cerro Verde in a privatization auction in 1994, when it bought a 91.65-percent stake in the firm and promised to invest $475 million over five years.
Cerro Verde is one of Peru's largest copper producers, accounting for nine percent of the country's annual output.
